{{short description|Form of discrimination}} {{Globalize|1=article|2=United States|date=January 2020}} {{Discrimination sidebar}} '''Employment discrimination''' is a form of illegal discrimination in the workplace based on legally protected characteristics. In the U.S., federal [[anti-discrimination law]] prohibits discrimination by employers against employees based on [[Ageism|age]], [[Race (human categorization)|race]], [[gender]], [[sex]] (including [[pregnancy]], [[sexual orientation]], and [[gender identity]]), [[religion]], [[national origin]], and [[Disability|physical or mental disability]]. State and local laws often protect additional characteristics such as [[marital status]], [[veteran]] status and [[caregiver]]/familial status.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Discrimination by Type {{!}} U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission |url=https://www.eeoc.gov/discrimination-type |access-date=2022-03-08 |website=www.eeoc.gov}}</ref> Earnings differentials or occupational differentiation—where differences in pay come from differences in qualifications or responsibilities—should not be confused with employment discrimination. Discrimination can be intended and involve [[disparate treatment]] of a group or be unintended, yet create [[disparate impact]] for a group.
== Definition == In [[neoclassical economics]] theory, labor market discrimination is defined as the different treatment of two equally qualified individuals on account of their [[gender]], [[race (biology)|race]], [[disability]], [[religion]], etc. [[Discrimination]] is harmful since it affects the economic outcomes of equally productive workers directly and indirectly through [[feedback]] effects.<ref name=Blau>{{cite book |last1=Blau |first1=Francine D. |last2=Ferber |first2=Marianne A. |last3=Winkler |first3=Anne E. | author-link1 = Francine D. Blau | author-link2 = Marianne Ferber |year=2010 |title=The Economics of Women, Men, and Work |chapter=Differences in Occupations and Earnings: The Role of Labor Market Discrimination |location=Harlow |publisher=Pearson Education |edition=6th international |isbn=978-0-1370-2436-0 }}</ref> Darity and Mason [1998] summarise that the standard approach used in identifying employment discrimination is to isolate group [[productivity]] differences ([[education]], work experience). Differences in outcomes (such as earnings, job placement) that cannot be attributed to worker qualifications are attributed to discriminatory treatment.<ref name=Darity>{{cite journal |last1=Darity |first1=William |first2=Patrick |last2=Mason |year=1998 |title=Evidence on Discrimination in Employment: Codes of Color, Codes of Gender |journal=[[Journal of Economic Perspectives]] |volume=12 |issue=2 |pages=63–90 |doi= 10.1257/jep.12.2.63|jstor=2646962 |url=http://www.aeaweb.org/articles.php?doi=10.1257/jep.12.2.63 |doi-access=free }}</ref>
In the non-neoclassical view, discrimination is the main source of inequality in the labor market and is seen in the persistent gender and [[racial wage gap in the United States|racial earnings disparity]] in the U.S.<ref name=Darity /> Non-neoclassical economists define discrimination more broadly than [[Neoclassical economics|neoclassical economists.]] For example, the feminist economist Deborah Figart [1997] defines labor market discrimination as "a multi-dimensional interaction of economic, social, political, and cultural forces in both the workplace and the family, resulting in different outcomes involving pay, employment, and status".<ref name=Figart>{{cite journal |last=Figart |first=Deborah |year=1997 |title=Gender as More than a Dummy Variable: Feminist Approaches to Discrimination |journal=Review of Social Economy |volume=55 |issue=1 |pages=1–32 |doi=10.1080/00346769700000022 |citeseerx=10.1.1.502.1629 }}</ref><!-- {{rp|237}} ! This source does not have a page 237 --> That is, discrimination is not only about measurable outcomes but also about unquantifiable consequences. It is important to note that the process is as important as the outcomes.<ref name=Figart /> Furthermore, gender [[norm (social)|norm]]s are embedded in [[labor markets]] and shape [[employer]] preferences as well worker preferences; therefore, it is not easy to separate discrimination from productivity-related inequality.<ref name=Elson>{{cite journal |last1=Elson |first1=Diane | author-link1 = Diane Elson |year=1999 |title=Labor markets as gendered institutions: equality, efficiency and empowerment issues |journal=World Development |volume=27 |issue=3 |pages=611–627 |doi=10.1016/S0305-750X(98)00147-8 }}</ref>
Although labor market inequalities have declined after the U.S. [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], the movement towards equality has slowed down after the mid-1970s, especially more in gender terms than racial terms.<ref name=Darity /><ref name=Sundstrom>{{cite journal |last=Sundstrom |first=William A. |year=1994 |title=The Color Line: Racial Norms and Discrimination in Urban Labor Markets, 1910–1950 |journal=[[Journal of Economic History]] |volume=54 |issue=2 |pages=382–396 |doi=10.1017/S0022050700014534 |s2cid=154689118 }}</ref> The key issue in the debate on employment discrimination is the persistence of discrimination, namely, why discrimination persists in a capitalist economy.<ref name=Darity />
== Evidence ==
=== Statistical === [[Gender earnings gap]] or the concentration of men and women workers in different occupations or industries in and of itself is not [[evidence]] of discrimination.<ref name=Blau /> Therefore, empirical studies seek to identify the extent to which earnings differentials are due to worker qualification differences. Many studies find that qualification differences do not explain more than a portion of the earnings differences. The portion of the earnings gap that cannot be explained by qualifications is then attributed by some{{Who|date=December 2021}} to discrimination. One prominent formal procedure for identifying the explained and unexplained portions of the gender wage differentials or wage gap is the [[Oaxaca–Blinder decomposition]] procedure.<ref name=Blau /><ref name=Darity />
Another type of statistical evidence of discrimination is gathered by focusing on [[homogeneous]] groups. This approach has the advantage of studying economic outcomes of groups with very similar qualifications.<ref name=Blau />
In a well-known longitudinal study, the [[University of Michigan Law School]] (U.S.A.) graduates were surveyed between 1987 and 1993, and later between 1994 and 2000 to measure the changes in the wage gap.<ref name=Noonen>{{cite journal |last1=Noonen |first1=Mary C. |first2=Mary E. |last2=Corcoran |first3=Paul |last3=Courant |year=2005 |title=Pay Differences Among the Highly Trained: Cohort Differences in the Sex Gap in Lawyers' Earnings |journal=Social Forces |volume=84 |issue=2 |pages=853–872 |doi=10.1353/sof.2006.0021 |s2cid=145425822 }}</ref> The group was intentionally chosen to have very similar characteristics. Although the gap in earnings between men and women was very small immediately after graduation, it widened in 15 years to the point that women earned 60 percent of what men earned. From the abstract: Sex differences in hours worked have increased over time and explain more of the sex-based earnings gap, while sex differences in job settings and years spent in private practice have declined and explain less of the gap.
Other studies on relatively homogeneous group of college graduates produced a similar unexplained gap, even for the highly educated women, such as [[Harvard Business School|Harvard MBAs]] in the United States. One such study focused on gender wage differences in 1985 between the [[college]] [[graduates]].<ref name=Weinberger>{{cite journal |last=Weinberger |first=Catherine J. |year=1998 |title=Race and Gender Wage Gaps in the Market for Recent College Graduates |journal=Industrial Relations |volume=37 |issue=1 |pages=67–84 |doi=10.1111/0019-8676.721998035 }}</ref> The graduates were chosen from the ones who earned their degree one or two years earlier. The researchers took college major, GPA (grade point average) and the educational institution the graduates attended into consideration. Yet, even after these factors were accounted for, there remained a 10-15 percent pay gap based on gender. Another study based on a 1993 survey of all college graduates had similar results for black and white women regarding gender differences in earnings.<ref name=Black>{{cite journal |last1=Black |first1=Dan A. |first2=Amelia M. |last2=Haviland |first3=Seth G. |last3=Sanders |first4=Lowell J. |last4=Taylor |year=2008 |title=Gender Wage Disparities Among the Highly Educated |journal=[[Journal of Human Resources]] |volume=43 |issue=3 |pages=630–659 |doi=10.3368/jhr.43.3.630 |pmid=26097255 |pmc=4470569 }}</ref> Both black women and white women made less money compared to white, non-Hispanic men. However, the results of earnings were mixed for [[Hispanic]] and Asian women when their earnings were compared to white, non-Hispanic men. A 2006 study looked at Harvard graduates.<ref name=Goldin>{{cite journal |last1=Goldin |first1=Claude |first2=Lawrence F. |last2=Katz |s2cid=111714286 |year=2008 |title=Transitions: Career and Family Life Cycles of the Educational Elite |journal=[[American Economic Review]] |volume=98 |issue=2 |pages=363–369 |jstor=29730048 |doi=10.1257/aer.98.2.363|url=http://www.aeaweb.org/articles.php?doi=10.1257/aer.98.2.363 }}</ref> The researchers also controlled for educational performance such as GPA, [[SAT]] scores and college major, as well as time out of work and current [[Job (role)|occupation]]. The results showed 30 percent of the wage gap was unexplained. Therefore, although not all of the unexplained gaps attribute to discrimination, the results of the studies signal gender discrimination, even if these women are highly educated.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Karamessini |first1=Maria |last2=Ioakimoglou |first2=Elias |date=January 2007 |title=Wage determination and the gender pay gap: A feminist political economy analysis and decomposition |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/13545700601075088 |journal=Feminist Economics |language=en |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=31–66 |doi=10.1080/13545700601075088 |s2cid=154518107 |issn=1354-5701}}</ref> Human capitalists argue that measurement and data problems contribute to this unexplained gap.<ref name=Noonen /><ref name=Weinberger /><ref name=Black /><ref name=Goldin />
One very recent example of employment discrimination is to be seen among female [[Chief Financial Officers]] (CFOs) in the US. Although 62% of accountants and auditors are women, they are only 9% when it comes to the CFO post. According to the research not only are they underrepresented in the profession, but they are also underpaid, 16% less on average.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cfo-insight.com/corporate-strategy/corporate-strategy/female-cfos-may-be-best-remedy-against-discrimination/ |title=Female CFOs May Be Best Remedy Against Discrimination |date=5 February 2013 |first=Max |last=Chase |work=CFO Insight |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130209181502/http://www.cfo-insight.com/corporate-strategy/corporate-strategy/female-cfos-may-be-best-remedy-against-discrimination/ |archive-date=2013-02-09 }}</ref>
=== From experiments === It is possible to investigate hiring discrimination experimentally by sending fabricated job applications to employers, where the fictitious candidates differ only by the characteristic to be tested (e.g. ethnicity, gender, age...).<ref name=":3" /> This method is also called correspondence testing.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rooth|first=Dan-Olof|date=2010-06-01|title=Automatic associations and discrimination in hiring: Real world evidence|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0927537109000451| journal=Labour Economics|language=en|volume=17|issue=3|pages=523–534| doi=10.1016/j.labeco.2009.04.005| issn=0927-5371}}</ref> If the researchers receive less positive replies for minority applicants, it can be concluded that this minority faces discrimination in hiring. A systematic review of 40 studies conducted between 2000 and 2014 found significant discrimination against ethnic minorities at all stages of the recruitment process, concluding that overall "race/ethnic minority groups needed to apply for nearly twice as many jobs as the majority group to get a positive response". When investigating gender-based discrimination, the same review concluded that "men applying for strongly female-stereotyped jobs need to make between twice to three times as many applications as do women to receive a positive response for these jobs" and "women applying to male-dominated jobs face lower levels of discrimination in comparison to men applying to female-dominated jobs." This study also identified discrimination based on age (against older workers), sexual orientation and obesity.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web| title = What Do Field Experiments of Discrimination in Markets Tell Us? A Meta Analysis of Studies Conducted since 2000| access-date = 2021-06-20| url = https://www.iza.org/publications/dp/8584/what-do-field-experiments-of-discrimination-in-markets-tell-us-a-meta-analysis-of-studies-conducted-since-2000}}</ref>
A meta-analysis of more than 700 correspondence test conducted between 1990 and 2015 concluded that "[ethnic] minority applicants have 49% lower odds to be invited for an interview, compared to the equally qualified majority candidate". However, they found no indication of any systematic discrimination based on gender.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1080/1369183X.2015.1133279| issn = 1369-183X| volume = 42| issue = 7| pages = 1115–1134| last1 = Zschirnt| first1 = Eva| last2 = Ruedin| first2 = Didier| title = Ethnic discrimination in hiring decisions: a meta-analysis of correspondence tests 1990–2015| journal = Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies| access-date = 2021-06-20| date = 2016-05-27| s2cid = 10261744| url = https://doi.org/10.1080/1369183X.2015.1133279}}</ref>
In a 2016 systematic review intending to list "(Almost) All Correspondence Experiments Since 2005", virtually all studies of racial discrimination found that ethnic minorities were disadvantaged. Of 11 studies that looked at gender discrimination, five found no evidence of discrimination, four found that women were advantaged, and two found that men were advantaged. Some studies also identified discrimination based on attractiveness, less physically-attractive people being less likely to be hired. <ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Springer International Publishing| isbn = 978-3-319-71153-9| pages = 63–77| editor = S. Michael Gaddis | last = Baert| first = Stijn| title = Audit Studies: Behind the Scenes with Theory, Method, and Nuance| chapter = Hiring Discrimination: An Overview of (Almost) All Correspondence Experiments Since 2005| location = Cham| series = Methodos Series| access-date = 2021-06-20| date = 2018| doi = 10.1007/978-3-319-71153-9_3| s2cid = 126102523| url = http://wps-feb.ugent.be/Papers/wp_17_936.pdf| chapter-url = https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-71153-9_3}}</ref>
A meta-analysis of 18 studies from various OECD countries found that gay and lesbian applicants face discrimination in hiring on the same level as ethnic discrimination.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1108/IJM-08-2018-0239| issn = 0143-7720| volume = 41| issue = 6| pages = 671–691| last = Flage| first = Alexandre| title = Discrimination against gays and lesbians in hiring decisions: a meta-analysis| journal = International Journal of Manpower| access-date = 2021-06-20| date = 2019-01-01| s2cid = 203476613| url = https://doi.org/10.1108/IJM-08-2018-0239}}</ref>
In 2021, a large-scale study published in ''Nature'' tracked the behavior of recruiters on a Swiss online recruitment platform. Based on more than 3 million profile views, they found that "immigrant and minority ethnic groups face a substantially lower contact rate compared to native Swiss citizens". The most affected groups were people from Asia (18.5% penalty) and Sub-Saharan Africa (17.1% penalty). On average, the study found "no evidence of meaningful differences between the contact rates of women and men". However, by looking separately at male-dominated and female-dominated occupations, the researchers found that women face a 6.7% hiring penalty in the 5 most male-dominated occupations (electrical workers, drivers, metal and machinery workers, construction and forestry/fishery/hunting). On the other hand, men face a 12.6% penalty when applying for jobs dominated by women (personal care, clerical support, health associates, clerks and health professionals).<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1038/s41586-020-03136-0| issn = 1476-4687| volume = 589| issue = 7843| pages = 572–576| last1 = Hangartner| first1 = Dominik| last2 = Kopp| first2 = Daniel| last3 = Siegenthaler| first3 = Michael| title = Monitoring hiring discrimination through online recruitment platforms| journal = Nature| access-date = 2021-06-20| date = January 2021| pmid = 33473211| bibcode = 2021Natur.589..572H| s2cid = 213021251| url = https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-020-03136-0}}</ref>
In 2013, a US based study showed Muslim hijab wearing women had a gap in call backs that women not wearing hijabs with the same employment profiles did not have. The study ran a field experiment of 49 male and 63 female employees from 72 retails stores and 40 restaurants with price points that targeted mid-income level clientele.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last1=Ghumman|first1=Sonia|last2=Ryan|first2=Ann Marie|date=2013-03-05|title=Not welcome here: Discrimination towards women who wear the Muslim headscarf|url=https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/0018726712469540|journal=Human Relations|language=en|volume=66|issue=5|pages=671–698|doi=10.1177/0018726712469540|s2cid=145608198|issn=0018-7267}}</ref> 14 women ages 19–22 and of varied ethnicities, volunteered to act as job applicants, "confederates".<ref name=":02"/> 14 additional women acted as "interaction observers."
