===== Religion ===== In Canada, a 2019 journal article drew data from the 2011 National Household Survey which after filtering for labor market relevant responders, had a sample size of 192,652 records.<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last1=Khattab|first1=Nabil|last2=Miaari|first2=Sami|last3=Mohamed-Ali|first3=Marwan|last4=Abu-Rabia-Queder|first4=Sarab|date=2019-06-01|title=Muslim women in the Canadian labor market: Between ethnic exclusion and religious discrimination|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0276562418301227|journal=Research in Social Stratification and Mobility|language=en|volume=61|pages=52–64|doi=10.1016/j.rssm.2018.11.006|hdl=1983/8faee968-34ed-49fb-8abe-3038e9bea6ff|s2cid=158552375|issn=0276-5624}}</ref> White Christian women were used as a baseline for the study.<ref name=":15" /> After comparing many ethno-religious groups against this baseline, they found that many ethno-religious groups, with the exception of Arab and Black Muslim women were as likely as White women to obtain managerial and professional jobs.<ref name=":15" /> Aside from those named exceptions, the study found Muslim women had the highest likelihood of unemployment and being disadvantaged.<ref name=":15" /> The article concludes that while it's possible that "discouraged women" and "surplus education" could explain low labor market participation and employment rates in Muslim women, the most likely cause is discrimination based on "visibility and religious affiliation"<ref name=":15" /> The article describes this visibility as "physical visibility and cultural proximity the dominant group [of Muslims]."<ref name=":15" /> This means that atop previously confirmed racial discrimination, racialized Muslims face the added penalty of being visibly and proximally Muslim.<ref name=":15" /> The study claims this is likely due to a rise in Islamophobia.<ref name=":15" /> A European study from the same year calls this "Muslim by default effect."<ref name=":23"/>
====United States==== {{further|Employment discrimination law in the United States}} =====Ethnicity===== The U.S. is one of the countries that have noticeable [[racial inequality in the United States|racial inequalities]]. Such inequalities are shown mostly between African Americans and whites. Although it is still uncertain if the reason behind the disparity leads to racism exclusively, different forms of interracial inequalities take place in the competitive labour market.
By means of their seminal correspondence experiment, Marianne Bertrand and Sendhil Mullainathan, showed that applications from job candidates with white-sounding names got 50 percent more callbacks for interviews than those with African-American-sounding names in the United States at the start of this millennium.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1257/0002828042002561|title = Are Emily and Greg More Employable Than Lakisha and Jamal? A Field Experiment on Labor Market Discrimination| journal=American Economic Review| volume=94| issue=4| pages=991–1013|year = 2004|last1 = Bertrand|first1 = Marianne| last2=Mullainathan| first2=Sendhil|url = http://s3.amazonaws.com/fieldexperiments-papers2/papers/00216.pdf}}</ref> Similarly, a 2009 study found that black applicants for low-wage jobs in New York City were half as likely as whites to get callbacks with equivalent resumes, interpersonal skills, and demographic characteristics.The same study also examines discrimination in the low-wage labour market, since the low-wage market contains a large proportion of service industries that require a higher demand for "soft skills." With a concern that employers might judge the applicant more subjectively in the low-wage labour market, the study discovers a minor sign of discrimination that black and Latino applicants were routinely channeled into positions requiring less customer contact and more manual work than their white counterparts. Employers appeared to see more potential in white applicants, and they more commonly considered white applicants as a better fit for jobs with higher responsibilities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pager|first1=D.|last2=Bonikowski|first2=B.|last3=Western|first3=B.|date=1 October 2009|title=Discrimination in a Low-Wage Labor Market: A Field Experiment|journal=American Sociological Review|volume=74|issue=5|pages=777–799|doi=10.1177/000312240907400505|pmc=2915472|pmid=20689685}}</ref>
A Current Population Survey in 2006 noted that African-Americans were twice as likely to be unemployed than whites.<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal |pmc = 2915460|year = 2008|last1 = Pager|first1 = D.|title = The Sociology of Discrimination: Racial Discrimination in Employment, Housing, Credit, and Consumer Markets|journal = Annual Review of Sociology|volume = 34|pages = 181–209|last2 = Shepherd|first2 = H.|pmid = 20689680|doi = 10.1146/annurev.soc.33.040406.131740}}</ref> "Black men spend significantly more time searching for work"; and even when they are working, they have less stable employment, diminishing their work experience".<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tomaskovic-Devey | first1 = D | last2 = Thomas | first2 = M | last3 = Johnson | first3 = K | year = 2005 | title = Race and the accumulation of humancapital across the career: a theoretical model and fixed-effects application | journal = Am. J. Sociol. | volume = 111 | pages = 58–89 | doi = 10.1086/431779 | s2cid = 145760818 }}</ref>
Discrimination goes beyond the hiring process. "Controlling for parental background, education, work experience, tenure, and training, white men earn roughly 15% more than comparable blacks."<ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 2096391|title = Reconsidering the Declining Significance of Race: Racial Differences in Early Career Wages|journal = American Sociological Review|volume = 61|issue = 4|pages = 541–556|last1 = Cancio|first1 = A. Silvia|last2 = Evans|first2 = T. David|last3 = Maume|first3 = David J.|year = 1996|doi = 10.2307/2096391}}</ref>
African Americans also face unfair discharges. Generally, people do not pay as much attention to unfair discharges as much as the hiring process. However, since there is barely any professional certification for supervisors, which is a crucial occupation for the process of both hiring and discharge in all industries, injustices might occur when a supervisor is consciously or unconsciously biased against certain racial groups. The Ohio Employment Discrimination Studies examined 8,051 claims of employment discrimination closed by the [[Ohio Civil Rights Commission]] (OCRC) from 1985 through 2001. The study is conducted to find a correlation between racial discrimination during the process of hiring and discharge. The study concludes that there is a significantly higher vulnerability of African American employees to discriminatory discharges, such as an African American employee would face a higher possibility of discharge by engaging in similar disruptive behavior in the workplace than a non-Black employee would face.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Slonaker|first1=William M.|last2=Wendt|first2=Ann C.|last3=Williams|first3=Scott David|date=February 2003|title=African American males in the front door but out the back door: monitor discharges|journal=Equal Opportunities International|volume=22|issue=1|pages=1–12|doi=10.1108/02610150310787289|issn=0261-0159}}</ref>
A study in 2014 shows that African American face more employment scrutiny than their white coworkers. In the study, a legal memorandum written by a hypothetical third-year associate was offered to two groups of partners who were from twenty-four law firms. The first group was told that the author was African American while the second group was told that the author to be a Caucasian. The study not only resulted in a lower average score graded by the first group (3.2 to 4.1 on a scale from 1 to 5,) but also the viewers inserted more captious grammar and spelling errors significantly when they believed the writer to be African American.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Eisenstadt|first1=Leora F.|last2=Boles|first2=Jeffrey R.|date=2016-10-26|title=Intent and Liability in Employment Discrimination|journal=American Business Law Journal|volume=53|issue=4|pages=607–675|doi=10.1111/ablj.12086|s2cid=147010802|issn=0002-7766}}</ref>
Within each race, darker complexion is also discriminated against. Multiple studies have found that lighter skin blacks "tend to have superior incomes and life chances". "Chicanos with lighter skin color and more european features had higher socioeconomic status" and "black Hispanics suffer close to ten times the proportionate income loss due to differential treatment of given characteristics than white Hispanics".<ref name=":19">{{cite journal | last1 = Darity | first1 = William A. | last2 = Mason | first2 = Patrick L. | year = 1998 | title = Evidence on discrimination in employment: Codes of color, codes of gender | url = http://www.aeaweb.org/articles.php?doi=10.1257/jep.12.2.63| journal = Journal of Economic Perspectives | volume = 12 | issue = 2| pages = 63–90 | doi=10.1257/jep.12.2.63| doi-access = free }}</ref>
The wage disparities between African American and Caucasian workers is a substantial expression of racial discrimination in the workplace. The historical trend of wage inequality between African American workers and Caucasian workers from 1940s to 1960s can be characterized by alternating periods of progress and retrenchment. From 1940 to 1950, the wage ratio for African-American men in comparison to white men rose from 0.43 to 0.55. From 1950 to 1960, however, the ratios only rose by 0.3, ending the decade at 0.58. The period from 1960 to 1980 has considerable progress for the wage ratio with an increase of 15 percent. This improvement was mostly due to the bans of discrimination from 1960 and abolition of [[Jim Crow laws|Jim Crow Laws]] by 1975. The late 1970s marked the beginning of a dramatic rise in overall wage inequality. A study shows that while both the wage of less educated and well-educated workers after 1979 declines, the wages of the least educated workers begin to fall dramatically faster.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mason|first=Patrick L.|date=May 1998|title=Race, Cognitive Ability, and Wage Inequality|journal=Challenge|volume=41|issue=3|pages=63–84|doi=10.1080/05775132.1998.11472033|issn=0577-5132}}</ref>
Over the past few decades, researchers argue around the explanation for the wage gap between the African American and Caucasian workers. [[James Heckman]], a Nobel Prize-winning American economist, leads the argument that labour market discrimination is ''no longer a first-order quantitative problem in American society,'' and supports the idea that blacks bring skill deficiencies to the labour market and cause the wage gap.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Coleman|first=Major G.|date=December 2003|title=Job Skill and Black Male Wage Discrimination*|journal=Social Science Quarterly|volume=84|issue=4|pages=892–906|doi=10.1046/j.0038-4941.2003.08404007.x|issn=0038-4941}}</ref> Heckman's argument is based on a series of papers utilizing the [[Armed Forces Qualification Test|Armed Forces Qualifications Test]] (AFQT) scores reported in the [[National Longitudinal Surveys|National Longitudinal Survey]] of Youth. The papers support that interracial wage inequality is due to pre-labour market inequality by examining the basic human capital model. The papers utilize empirically based approach suggesting that an individual's position in the skill distribution is influenced by the decisions made reconsidering the cost and benefit of acquiring certain jobs. The researchers who support the approach believe that in a competitive labour market individuals of equal ability is rewarded equally.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mason|first=P. L.|date=1999-05-01|title=Male interracial wage differentials: competing explanations|journal=Cambridge Journal of Economics|volume=23|issue=3|pages=261–299|doi=10.1093/cje/23.3.261|issn=1464-3545}}</ref>
On the other hand, the researchers who favor the explanation that racial discrimination is the reason that causes wage inequality argues against the reliability of AFQT. AFQT is a test based on a single dataset and intended to predict performance in military service. The predictions of the analysis have not been replicated by studies that employ different measures of cognitive skills, and it yields inconsistent results on pre-labor market skill differences between races. Therefore, it is unable to summarize that the impact of pre-labour inequality would directly cause skill deficiencies.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mason|first=Patrick L.|date=September 2000|title=Understanding Recent Empirical Evidence on Race and Labor Market Outcomes in the USA|journal=Review of Social Economy|volume=58|issue=3|pages=319–338|doi=10.1080/00346760050132355|s2cid=145287824|issn=0034-6764}}</ref>
===== Sex ===== {{main|Occupational sexism|Motherhood penalty}}
Women have had a long history of discrimination in the workplace. Feminist theory points to the concept of a [[family wage]]- a rate substantial enough to support a man and his family- as the explanation to why women's labor is cheap, claiming it preserves "male dominance and women's dependence in the family".<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal |jstor = 189578|title = Bringing Gender and Race in: U.S. Employment Discrimination Policy|journal = Gender and Society|volume = 7|issue = 2|pages = 204–226|last1 = Blankenship|first1 = Kim M.|year = 1993|doi = 10.1177/089124393007002004|s2cid = 144175260}}</ref> Though there has been legislation such as the [[Equal Pay Act of 1963|Equal Pay Act]] that combat gender discrimination, the implications of the act are limited. "As an amendment to the Fair Labor Standard Act, it exempted employers in agriculture, hotels, motels, restaurants, and laundries, as well as professional, managerial, and administrative personnel, outside salesworkers, and private household workers". Because high concentrations of women work in these fields (34.8% of employed women of color and 5.1% of white women as private household workers, 21.6% and 13.8% working in service jobs, 9.3% and 3.7% as agricultural workers, and 8.1% and 17.2% as administrative workers), "nearly 45% of all employed women, then, appear to have been exempt from the Equal Pay Act".<ref name=":2" />
The hourly wage rate for women is 65% of that of men, and annual earnings of full-time employed women is 71% of that of men (potential range discrepancy identified within quoted statistic - "The Economics of Women, Men and Work" 3rd Edition). Among the male wage distribution, the average woman lies at the 33rd percentile.<ref>Blau, Francine D., M. Ferber, and A. Winkler, ''The Economics of Women, Men, and Work'', third edition. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall, 1998.</ref>
Within women, another level of discrimination takes place among mothers. Historically, this inequality stems from the belief that mothers are less productive at work. Visibly pregnant women are often judged as less committed to their jobs, less dependable, and more emotional compared to women who are not visibly pregnant.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal | last1 = Correll | first1 = Shelley J. | last2 = Benard | first2 = Stephen | last3 = Paik | first3 = In | year = 2007 | title = Getting a Job: Is There a Motherhood Penalty? | url = http://s3.amazonaws.com/fieldexperiments-papers2/papers/00227.pdf| journal = American Journal of Sociology | volume = 112 | issue = 5| pages = 1297–1338 | doi=10.1086/511799| s2cid = 7816230 }}</ref> A study conducted in 1998 showed that the wage rates of women without children were 81.3% of men's pay, but 73.4% of men's pay for women with children.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1257/jep.12.1.137|title = Understanding the 'Family Gap' in Pay for Women with Children|journal = Journal of Economic Perspectives|volume = 12|pages = 137–156|year = 1998|last1 = Waldfogel|first1 = Jane|doi-access = free}}</ref> An audit study in 2007 found that, childless women receive 2.1 times as many callbacks than equally qualified mothers. Though it does not receive as much attention as the gender gap, motherhood is a significant quality that is discriminated against. In fact, the pay gap between mothers and non-mothers is larger than the pay gap between men and women.<ref name=":6" />
=====Gender and sexual orientation===== The [[Williams Institute]], a national think tank at [[UCLA School of Law]], released a 2011 report<ref name="The Williams Institute">{{cite web | url=http://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/wp-content/uploads/Sears-Mallory-Discrimination-July-20111.pdf |title=Documented Evidence of Employment Discrimination & Its Effects on LGBT People | publisher=The Williams Institute | access-date=25 November 2014}}</ref> that has identified sexual orientation and gender identification discrimination in the workplace. According to the report, between 15-43% of lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender workers have experienced being fired, denied promotions, or harassed due to their sexual orientation or gender identification.<ref name="The Williams Institute"/> Additionally, 27 states do not have statewide laws for protecting LGBTQ people from [[LGBT employment discrimination in the United States|discrimination based on sexual orientation]] or gender identity in employment, housing, and public accommodations.<ref>{{Cite web|title=LGBTQ Americans Aren't Fully Protected From Discrimination in 29 States|url=https://freedomforallamericans.org/states/|access-date=2021-12-10|website=Freedom for All Americans|language=en}}</ref> Wisconsin and New Hampshire prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation but not gender identity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/map/non-discrimination-laws-state-state-information-map|title=Non-Discrimination Laws: State by State Information - Map|access-date=2016-09-20}}</ref> On October 4, 2017 Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]] announced that the [[United States Department of Justice]] will no longer provide employment protection to [[transgender]] individuals under Title VII of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]], reversing the position of former Attorney General [[Eric Holder]], during the Obama administration.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Glasser|first1=Nathaniel M.|last2=Rhodes|first2=Kate B.|title=Attorney General Reverses Obama-Era Protection of Transgender Employees|url=https://www.natlawreview.com/article/attorney-general-reverses-obama-era-protection-transgender-employees|access-date=15 October 2017|work=The [[National Law Review]]|publisher=Epstein Becker & Green, P.C.|date=3 October 2017}}</ref> However, on June 15, 2020, the U.S. Supreme Court in a 6–3 decision concluded that Title VII protects gay, lesbian, and transgender individuals from sex-based discrimination in the workplace.<ref>{{Cite web|date=June 15, 2020|title=U.S. Supreme Court decision in Bostock v. Clayton County, Georgia|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/19pdf/17-1618_hfci.pdf|website=U.S. Supreme Court Archives}}</ref>
=====Age===== Most age discrimination occurs among the older workers when employers hold negative stereotypes about them. Though evidence on declines in productivity is inconsistent, "other evidence points to declines in acuteness of vision or hearing, ease of memorization, computational speed, etc.". Another factor employers take into consideration is the higher cost of health or life insurance for older workers.<ref name=":143">{{cite journal | last1 = Neumark | first1 = D | year = 2003 | title = Age discrimination legislations in the United States | url = http://www.socsci.uci.edu/~dneumark/Neumark%20CEP%202003.pdf | journal = Contemporary Economic Policy | volume = 21 | issue = 3| pages = 297–317 | doi=10.1093/cep/byg012| s2cid = 38171380 }}</ref>
A 2013 report<ref name="AARP">{{cite web | url=http://www.aarp.org/content/dam/aarp/research/surveys_statistics/econ/2013/Staying-Ahead-of-the-Curve-Age-Discrimination.pdf |title= Staying Ahead of the Curve 2013: AARP Multicultural Work and Career Study Perceptions of Age Discrimination in the Workplace – Ages 45-74 | publisher=AARP | page=1 | access-date=25 November 2014}}</ref> was completed by the [[AARP]] to identify the impact of [[ageism|age discrimination]] in the workplace. Of those 1500 individuals who responded to AARP's 2013 Staying Ahead of the Curve survey, almost 64% of those over 45–74 said they have seen or have experienced age discrimination in the workplace. Of those, 92% say it was somewhat or very common in their workplace.<ref name="AARP" /> "In 1963 the unemployment rate for men over age 55 was a full percentage point higher (4.5 percent) than for men aged 35-54 (3.5%)." Average durations of unemployment are higher for older workers as well- 21 weeks for men over age 45 as opposed to 14 weeks for men under 45.<ref name=":143"/>
=====Criminal records===== {{main|Employment discrimination against persons with criminal records in the United States}} Laws restricting employment discrimination for persons who have been convicted of criminal offenses vary significantly by state.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gaines|first1=Joshua|title=State licensing laws unfairly restrict opportunities for people with criminal records|url=http://ccresourcecenter.org/2016/04/28/state-licensing-laws-unfairly-restrict-opportunities-for-people-with-criminal-records/|website=Collateral Consequences Resource Center|access-date=15 August 2017|date=28 April 2016}}</ref> The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has issued guidelines for employers, intended to prevent criminal record discrimination from being used as a proxy to effect unlawful racial discrimination.<ref>{{cite web|title=Consideration of Arrest and Conviction Records in Employment Decisions Under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964|url=https://www.eeoc.gov/laws/guidance/arrest_conviction.cfm|website=Equal Employment Opportunity Commission|access-date=15 August 2017|date=25 April 2012}}</ref>
===== Religion ===== In the US, a journal article using pooled data from a 2007 and 2011 probability sample of Muslims living in the United States, found that there was a key difference in the employment of hijab-wearing Muslim women versus non-hijab wearing Muslims but little difference in the employment of non-hijab wearing Muslim women and non-Muslim women; it calls this the "hijab effect".<ref name=":33">{{Cite journal|last=Abdelhadi|first=Eman|date=2019-06-01|title=The Hijab and Muslim women's employment in the United States|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0276562418301239|journal=Research in Social Stratification and Mobility|language=en|volume=61|pages=26–37|doi=10.1016/j.rssm.2019.01.006|s2cid=159332697|issn=0276-5624}}</ref> The study controls for demographic variables, migration history, human capital, and house hold composition to analyze "inter-religious" differences and "intra-Muslim" differences.<ref name=":33" /> Intra-Muslim differences looks at non-hijab wearing Muslim women and hijab wearing Muslim women. The article states that "conservative gender ideology" is not correlated with Muslim women's employment in the US.<ref name=":33" /> It suggests two possible reasons for the hijab effect.<ref name=":33" /> The first possible reason is employers discriminating against hijab wearing Muslim women during the hiring process.<ref name=":33" /> The second possible reason is that career oriented or job-driven Muslim women may feel less free to wear hijab or may not wear it to display their "careerism or avoid discrimination."<ref name=":33" /> The study can not provide direct evidence for employment discrimination.<ref name=":33" /> The researchers conclude that the study suggests non-structural discrimination.<ref name=":33" />
Another study in the United States rans a field experiment with women posing as job applicants/"confederates" and interaction "observers."<ref name=":02"/> Each pair of observer and confederate entered eight different locations serving a similar demographic.<ref name=":02" /> The observer acted as clientele and timed interactions, while the confederate asked questions based on a script and training.<ref name=":02" /> Half of the time confederate wore hijab and the other times they did not wear hijab. Using this data the study concluded that there is formal and interpersonal discrimination against hijab wearing Muslim women.<ref name=":02" /> Formal discrimination, also referred to as overt discrimination, defined as conscious, explicit biases against a protected group. This was measured by.<ref name=":02" /> Interpersonal discrimination, also referred to as covert discrimination, defined as being less cordial, more disinterested and curt with protected groups.<ref name=":02" />
